intro: Lupinaster buxbaumii, commonly known as the Buxbaum's lupinaster, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which is characterized by its leguminous properties and nitrogen-fixing capabilities. The plant produces showy, violet to blue flowers that bloom in late spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its leaves are compound, consisting of several small, oval-shaped leaflets. Lupinaster buxbaumii is adapted to thrive in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a resilient species in desert environments.
